Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story: I stared at my screen, the error message taunting me for the third hour in a row. As a mentee, I knew I was supposed to reach out to my mentor whenever I hit a wall, but this technical hurdle felt like something I should be able to solve on my own. I didn’t want to seem incapable or needy. At the same time, as a software developer, I was getting pinged by QA about a minor UI glitch. It wasn’t critical—users could easily work around it—but the expectation was clear: fix bugs quickly, keep the product clean. My inbox was filling up with reminders, but my mind kept circling back to the bigger problem I couldn’t crack. I felt torn—should I admit my struggle to my mentor and risk looking incompetent, or push through and risk letting the bug linger longer than it should? The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I found myself frozen, unable to decide which expectation to meet first.
